questions.question: Which of the following lesions does not arise from the terminal duct lobular unit of thebreast?
Which of the following lesions arise from the large ducts of the breast?
questions.explanation: Duct ectasia and Paget's disease arise from the large ducts of the breast.Normal anatomy of the breast includes ducts, lobules, and stroma. Successive branching of thelarge ducts eventually leads to the terminal duct lobular unit.Atypical hyperplasia arises from the terminal ducts and lobules, whereas, fibroadenomaand phyllodes tumors arise from the intralobular stroma.

questions.question: A 28-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast. On examination, younotice her nipple is erythematous and tender with a purulent exudate. Which of the followingis the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mastitis. The most common cause of acutemastitis is Staphylococcus aureus.Acute bacterial mastitis typically occurs during the 1st month of breastfeeding (lactational breastabscess). It is caused by a local bacterial infection when the breast is most vulnerable due tocracks and fissures in the nipples.Staphylococcal acute mastitis typically results in localized abscesses.1191Option A: Breast abscess caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is uncommon, only a few cases havebeen documented in immunocompromised patients.Options B and C: Streptococcal infections tend to spread throughout the breast in the form ofcellulitis.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is most strongly associated with a history of smoking?
questions.explanation: Periductal mastitis is strongly associated with a history of smoking. More than 90% of theaffected individuals are smokers.Periductal mastitis is also called recurrent subareolar abscess or squamous metaplasia oflactiferous ducts or Zuska disease. In this condition, a relative deficiency of vitamin A associatedwith smoking or toxic substances in tobacco smoke alters the differentiation of the ductalepithelium.Histologically, there is keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the nipple ducts. Keratin shed fromthese cells is trapped and plugs (keratin plug) the ductal system, causing dilation and eventuallyrupture of the duct. This results in keratin spillage into the surrounding periductal tissue forminga chronic granulomatous inflammatory response.It presents with a painful erythematous subareolar mass that clinically mimics bacterial abscess.It has a high recurrence rate.Squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ductsLactiferous ductopening at nippleMAStratified squamousepithelium occludingthe duotKeratin plugNormal lactiferous duotSquamous metaplasia of lactiferous ductOMARROWStratifiedsquamousepitheliumSmoothmuscle ofareolaNormalcuboidalepitheliumFistula at theedge of areolaAbscess

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presented with a painless palpable lump in her left breast. She hadsustained a traumatic blow to her left breast 1 month back. Mammography showed aradiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucentcystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis.About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma orprevious surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or1192mammographic densities or calcifications.Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, andchronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification.The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue.NecroticadipocytesCholesterolcleftsNote: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions -.•Apocrine cysts• Hyalinized fibroadenomas• Sclerosing adenosis• Duct ectasia• Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcification(microcalcifications).

questions.question: Which of the following is a proliferative breast lesion?
questions.explanation: Papillomas are classified under proliferative breast diseases without atypia.Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and usually have no genetic changes.Thus they are predictors of risk but are not true precursors of carcinoma.Benign epithelial lesions are classified into three groups, according to the subsequent risk ofdeveloping breast cancer. These are:•⚫ Non-proliferative breast changes• Proliferative breast disease without atypial•Atypical hyperplasiaNote: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion withassociated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of1193metastases.

questions.question: All of the following lesions are proliferative breast lesions without atypia except:
questions.explanation: Duct ectasia is a non-proliferative breast change.Radial scar, sclerosing adenosis, and florid hyperplasia belong to proliferative breast lesionswithout atypia.Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and are not commonly found to havegenetic changes. Thus they are predictors of risk but unlikely to be true precursors of carcinoma.

questions.question: What is the most common clinical presentation seen in patients with duct papilloma?1180
questions.explanation: The most common clinical presentation seen in patients with duct papilloma is nippledischarge. More than 80% of large duct papillomas produce a nipple discharge.Papillomas grow within a dilated duct and are composed of multiple branching fibrovascularcores. It can be serous or bloody.• Serous discharge - due to intermittent blockage and release of normal breast secretions orirritation of the duct by the papilloma• Bloody discharge - due to torsion of the stalk, causing infarction

questions.question: A young man presents to your clinic with the following finding. Which of the following is notassociated with this condition?
questions.explanation: The image given depicts gynecomastia. Seminoma is not a cause of this condition.Gynecomastia occurs due to increased estrogenic action. The most common causes ofgynecomastia include:••Cirrhosis of the liver• AlcoholMarijuana, heroin• Antiretroviral therapy• Anabolic steroids•⚫ Klinefelter syndrome (XXY karyotype)•⚫ Functioning testicular neoplasms such as Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumorsMicroscopically, there is an increase in the dense collagenous connective tissue. It is associatedwith epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobuleformation is almost never observed.1194

questions.question: A biopsy was performed on a female patient who presented with a lump in her right breast. Presence of which of the following findings is not associated with an increased risk of cancer?
questions.explanation: Apocrine change does not increase the risk of cancer as it is a non-proliferative change. Moderate or florid hyperplasia, fibroadenoma with complex features, and sclerosing adenosis are classified under proliferative disease without atypia with a 1.5- to 2-fold increased risk of carcinoma. Both breasts are at increased risk, although the risk to the ipsilateral breast may be slightly higher.

questions.question: While undergoing a routine mammogram, a 45-year-old woman was found to have clusters ofmicrocalcification in her right breast. A needle biopsy was done and revealed the following.Which of the following markers can be used to rule out invasive disease?
questions.explanation: The given image is suggestive of the comedo type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).Myoepithelial cell markers like p63 can differentiate DCIS from invasive carcinoma.Ductal Carcinoma In-Situ - Comedo PatternDuctal Carcinoma In-Situ - Comedo PatternRapidly proliferatingductal tumor cellsCentral necrosis1195DCIS is a malignant clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by theintact basement membrane. It is rarely palpable and is almost always detected by mammography.Myoepithelial cells (basal cell layer) are preserved in involved ducts or lobules in DCIS. Hence themyoepithelial cell markers like p63, basal cytokeratin (CK 5/6), calponin will be positive in DCISwhereas it will be absent in infiltrating ductal carcinoma. However, myoepithelial markers may bediminished in high-grade DCIS compared to surrounding normal ducts or lobules.Once the tumor cells penetrate through the basement membrane and grow within the stroma,they are considered to be invasive carcinoma.Histological appearance ofDuctal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)Papillary patternThe increased proliferation of the epitheliumthat lines the minor ducts results in thepapillary growths within the duct luminaCribriform patternThe papillary growths eventually coalesceand fill the duct lumina so that only scattered,rounded spaces remain between the clumpsof atypical cancer cellsSolid patternPleomorphic cancer cells eventuallyobliterate the lumina and distend the ductsComedo patternWith the rapid proliferation of cells, somecells do not get adequate blood supply andbecome necrotic. The ducts are filled with thenecrotic materialNote: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion withassociated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable ofmetastases.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with persistent soreness and itching in her right nipple. Onexamination, the following finding is noted. What would be the next best step in hermanagement?1182
questions.explanation: The given scenario showing a red eczematous rash over the areola of the breast is suggestiveof Paget's disease of the nipple. The next best step in management is biopsy of the nipple.Paget's disease can be mistaken for eczema, and hence, biopsy of the nipple should be the initialmanagement of choice. Paget cells are readily detected by nipple biopsy.

questions.question: Histopathological examination of a middle-aged woman who presented with redness anditching over the nipple of her left breast is given below. Which of the following statements isincorrect about her condition?

options.C: Prognosis depends on the underlying carcinoma
options.D: The cells show overexpression of HER2

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing Paget's cells (malignant cells with abundant palecytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei) are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. These cells areER-negative.Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare form of ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). The characteristicPaget's cells are scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. They do not breach1196the basement membrane but extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin.The following images show Paget's cells that do not breach the basement membrane.Paget's disease of the nipplePaget cellIt presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust. A palpable mass is seen inabout half the patients with this disease.The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2.The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma.Paget's disease may mimic the following conditions:• Eczema (clinical appearance) - can be differentiated by the presence of malignant cells on biopsySuperficial spreading melanoma (histological appearance) - Paget's cells are PAS-positive anddiastase resistant unlike melanoma cells•Note: Paget's disease of the bone is a distinct condition that results in abnormal bone metabolismdue to osteoclastic overactivity.1197

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for breast cancer?
questions.explanation: Early full-term pregnancy (younger than 20 years) is protective against breast cancer. It halves therisk of developing breast cancer compared to that of nulliparous women.Women with very dense breasts on mammography have a four- to six-fold higher risk of bothER-positive and ER-negative breast cancer compared to women with low density.Obese women under the age of 40 years have a decreased risk as a result of anovulatory cycles andlower progesterone levels. In contrast, postmenopausal obese women are at an increased risk,which is attributed to the synthesis of estrogens in fat depots.Early menarche, late menopause, and nulliparity are risk factors of breast cancer due tohyperestrogenemia. Exercise and breastfeeding are protective against breast cancer.

questions.question: What is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast?
questions.explanation: The upper outer quadrant is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast.Approximately 50% of carcinomas are located in the upper outer quadrant, 10% in each of theremaining quadrants, and about 20% in the central or subareolar region.A palpable mass is the most common clinical sign of invasive breast carcinoma.Triple assessment is recommended for the diagnosis of any palpable breast lump. It includes:• Clinical examination•Radiological assessment (mammography/USG)• Pathological assessment (FNAC/biopsy)Techniques of palpation for breast examination are:• Vertical strip/lines pattern•Circular pattern•Wedges or radial spokes pattern1198Techniques of breast palpationCirclesWedgesLinesMARROW

questions.question: On which of the following chromosomes is the BRCA2 gene located?
questions.explanation: BRCA2 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q12.3). Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are responsible for 80 to 90% of single-gene familial breast cancers and about 3% of all breast cancers. ER-positive, HER2-negative cancers (luminal type) are the most common subtype of breast cancer in individuals who inherit germline mutations in BRCA2. This gene is associated more frequently with male breast cancer. Single-gene mutations associated with familial breast cancer can be categorized into: • High penetrance germline mutations (>4 fold increased risk) - BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, STK11, CDH1, PALB2 • Moderate penetrance germline mutations (2-4 fold increased risk) - ATM, CHEK2

questions.question: Immunohistochemical testing was performed on a biopsy sample taken from a patient withbreast cancer. It revealed lack of expression of ER, PR, and HER2. Which of the followinggenes is most commonly mutated in this condition?1184
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of triple-negative breast cancer (ER-negative, PR-negative, andHER2-negative). TP53 is the most commonly mutated gene in triple-negative breast cancer(TNBC).Common gene mutations in the 3 major molecular types of invasive breast carcinoma are:Molecular SubtypeLuminal (ER+/HER2-)Common gene mutationsLuminal A: PIK3CA (more common), TP53Luminal B: PIK3CA (more common), TP531199Molecular SubtypeHER2 Positive (HER2+)ATNBC (ER-/ HER2-)Common gene mutationsTP53 (more common), PIK3CTP53 (more common), PIK3CA

questions.question: A 44-year-old woman has been diagnosed with breast carcinoma. Immunohistochemistrystaining of a tissue biopsy specimen of this patient is given below. Which of the followingstatements is true regarding her condition?H&EERPRHER2

options.B: It is not associated with tP53 mutationsPoor response to paclitaxeld) Good response to trastuzumabQuestion 19:Immunohistochemistry test of a breast cancer patient was reported negative for ER andHER2. This molecular subtype includes all of the following except:a) Secretory carcinomab) Spindle cell carcinoma

questions.explanation: The given immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining shows positive ER, PR (brown nucleus), andnegative Her-2 (no membrane-bound brown stain) expression, which is suggestive of luminal Amolecular subtype. It shows a poor response to paclitaxel.Hormone receptors (ER, PR) are present in the nucleus. Therefore ER, PR-positive breast cancercells will stain dark in the nucleus on IHC. Her-2 receptors are membrane-bound receptors, andhence, cells having these receptors are darkly stained on the membranes.Luminal A type is more commonly associated with BRCA2 mutations.Hormone receptor-positive tumors are responsive to hormonal chemotherapeutic agents liketamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors. In Her-2 negative cases, trastuzumab is not effective as it is arecombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against HER-2.The following image shows ER/PR/ Her-2 positivity:ERPRHER2Note: At least 10% of luminal type A breast cancers express tp53 mutations. tP53 mutations areassociated with triple-negative tumors as well.

questions.question: Patients with all of the following conditions have ER-positive and HER2-negative tumorsexcept:
questions.explanation: ER-positive, HER2-negative status on immunohistochemistry is suggestive of the luminal type ofbreast carcinoma, which does not include secretory carcinoma.The ER-positive, HER2-negative molecular subtype (luminal type) commonly includes thefollowing histological subtypes:.• Well and poorly differentiated lobular carcinoma• Tubular carcinoma•Mucinous carcinoma• Papillary carcinomaSecretory carcinomas are usually ER-negative and Her2/neu negative (basal type).

questions.question: Which of the following breast cancers most commonly presents as an occult primarycarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Lobular carcinoma is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primarycarcinoma.Lobular carcinoma of the breast is seen bilaterally and with multicentricity. Loss of E-cadherin isthe hallmark of lobular carcinoma. They also have characteristic patterns of metastatic spread,often involving the peritoneum and retroperitoneum, leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis),gastrointestinal tract, ovaries, and uterus.The histological hallmark of lobular carcinoma is the presence of discohesive infiltrating tumorcells, often arranged in a single Indian file pattern or in loose clusters or sheets.1201Lobular carcinoma of breastIndian file pattern

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of lobular breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation: There is no or very slight desmoplastic response seen in lobular carcinomas.Desmoplasia refers to collagenous stromal proliferation induced by tumor cells which is essentialfor tumor growth and spread. It results in hard and stony tumors. However, this is not seen inlobular carcinoma. This is likely due to the loss of expression of CDH1, the gene thatencodes e-cadherin (normally maintains intercellular adhesiveness). This also resultsin disaggregation of cells.Lobular carcinomas are often bilateral and multicentric. It shows characteristic metastatic spread,often involving:• Peritoneum and retro peritoneum• Leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis)• Gastrointestinal tract•• Ovaries• UterusHistopathological image of invasive lobular carcinoma of breast showing discohesive cells withfew signet ring cells.1202Lobular Carcinoma of BreastLobular Carcinoma of BreastSignet ring cellsDiscohesive cellsNote: Individuals with heterozygous germline mutations in CDH1 (loss of E-cadherin) also have agreatly increased risk of gastric signet-ring cell carcinoma.

questions.question: A 53-year-old woman with breast cancer is found to have TNM staging of T4dNoMo. Whichof the following statements is true regarding her condition?

options.A: There is loss of e-cadherin expression
options.B: It has a relatively favorable prognosis1186
options.C: There is obstruction of dermal lymphatics by neoplastic cells
options.D: History of trauma to the breast is usually present

questions.explanation: T4d in the TNM staging of carcinoma breast points toward a diagnosis of inflammatory breastcarcinoma. It shows extensive invasion and proliferation of tumor cells within the dermallymphatics leading to obstruction.Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The hallmark of thiscondition is the overexpression of e-cadherin. This results in increased tumor cohesion and theformation of tumoral clumps which can result in emboli. It has a particularly poor prognosis.1203These tumors are usually of high grade but do not belong to any particular molecularsubtype. More than half (60%) are ER-negative and 40% to 50% overexpress HER2. There is noassociation with trauma.Due to lymphatic obstruction, it results in brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, andedema called peau d'orange appearance. This may mimic non-neoplastic inflammatory lesionslike mastitis. A breast lump may or may not be present.The following image shows a peau d'orange appearance of the right breast.

questions.question: Immunohistochemistry for HER2 protein expression is performed in 3 patients with breastcarcinoma, with the following results. Which of the following patients should be subjected tofluorescence in-situ hybridization?A
questions.explanation: The immunohistochemistry (IHC) pattern of patient C reveals moderately strong circumferentialstaining (faint brown color) in >10 % of cells, which is classified as 2+ or equivocal staining.Hence, she should be subjected to fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirmHER2-positive gene amplification status.1204Patient A1+HER2-negativePatient B3+HER2-positive: Strong circumferentialmembrane staining in >10% cellsPatient C2+Equivocal - moderately strongcircumferential staining in >10 % of cells1205The following are classified as HER2-positive tumors:⚫ Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not needed).• Tumors with 2+ staining on IHC, followed by HER2-gene amplification confirmed by FISHOnce HER2-positive status is confirmed, targeted therapy against HER2 can be initiated withtrastuzumab or lapatinib.

questions.question: A middle-aged woman is diagnosed with low-grade mucinous carcinoma of the breast. IHCshowed HER2 overexpression and a low Ki67 index. Which of the following would beconsidered as a poor prognostic factor?
questions.explanation: HER2 overexpression in a patient with carcinoma breast is associated with poor survival.The main importance of HER2 status is as a predictor of response to agents that target thisreceptor.Prognostic and predictive factors in breast carcinoma:Extent and spreadSizeHistological subtypeHistologic gradeGood prognosisIn situ carcinomaSize <1 cmTubular carcinomaMucinouscarcinomaLobular carcinomaPapillary carcinomaAdenoidcystic carcinomaLow gradeLuminal A subtypeBad prognosisInvasive carcinomaLocally advanced disease Lymphovascular invasionDistant metastasisSize >2 cmMetaplastic carcinoma Micropapillary carcinomaHigh gradeMolecular subtypeHer2-enriched and basal subtypeProliferation rate(Ki67 index& mitotic counts)Low proliferation rateHigh proliferation rate

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman on cyclosporin-A following renal transplantation developed multiplebilateral breast lumps that regressed after cessation of treatment. Her biopsy finding isshown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing duct proliferation are suggestive of fibroadenomas. Theuse of cyclosporin-A after transplantation is associated with fibroadenomas that regress aftercessation of the treatment.1206Fibroadenoma of BreastIntracanalicular patternPericanalicular patternFibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. Nearly 2/3 cases areassociated with mutations in the MED12 gene.They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women <30 years of age. Theyare solid, well-defined, highly mobile masses (also known as breast mice).Fibroadenomas can be classified into 2 types:• Without complex features - classified as a non-proliferative condition•With complex features -• Associated with cysts > 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillaryapocrine change• Classified as proliferative changes without atypia

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman presented with a large, rapidly growing painless breast lump. Onexamination, a smooth, multinodular breast lump was noticed. Microscopic examination ofthe core biopsy sample is shown below. Which of the following is an incorrect statementregarding this condition?1188

options.B: Stromal cellularity is increased next to the epithelium
options.C: Absence of epithelial elements suggests malignancy
options.D: Both epithelial and stromal components can metastasize

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Here, only the stromalcomponent is involved in metastasis.1207EpitheliumPhyllodes TumorPhyllodes TumorLeaf-like architectureIncreasedstromalcellularityPhyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial tumor arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as asmooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable. It mostcommonly presents in the 6th decade of life and is associated with:•Gain in chromosome 1q• HOXB13 overexpressionPhyllodes tumors show stromal cellularity next to the epithelium (subepithelial orperiepithelial regions). This feature helps to differentiate it from intracanalicular fibroadenoma.The prognosis of phyllodes tumors depends on their histological grade. Most phyllodes tumors arelow grade, with limited stromal cellularity. They recur only occasionally and do not metastasize.The features of malignant (intermediate and high grade) phyllodes tumors are:• Markedly increased stromal cellularity• Stromal overgrowth - absence of epithelial elements1208• Nuclear atypia• Increased mitosis (>10/ 10 hpf).Highly recurrentRegardless of the grade, lymphatic spread is rare in phyllodes tumors. Hence, axillary lymph nodedissection is contraindicated.

questions.question: What is the most common stromal malignancy in the breast?
questions.explanation: Angiosarcoma is the most common stromal malignancy in the breast.It arises in the interlobular stroma and accounts for < 0.05% of breast malignancies. It is ahigh-grade tumor with a poor prognosis. It can either be sporadic or occur in association withradiation therapy. The mean age of affected individuals is 35 years.

questions.question: BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of renal cell carcinoma. BRCA-2 mutation predisposes to the development of prostate and pancreatic cancer. It is also associated with an increased risk of male breast cancer.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast.Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intracellular and extracellularmucin deposition.On histopathological examination, extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei, arrangedin clusters, floating in lakes or pools of mucin. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to theperiphery to form a signet ring appearance.1209Colloid Carcinoma of BreastColloid Carcinoma of BreastNests of cellsLakes of mucinOption B: Microscopic image of papillary carcinoma of the breast showing true papillae with aleaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue lined by the tumor cells is shown below.1210Papillary Carcinoma of BreastPapillary Carcinoma of BreastRapidly proliferatingepithelial tumor cellsFibrovasculartissueOption C: Microscopic image of medullary carcinoma of the breast consisting of sheets of highlypleomorphic cells with mitotic figures (anaplastic cells), lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate is shownbelow.1211Histology of medullary carcinoma breastLymphocyticinfiltrationAnaplasticcellsOption D: Microscopic image of lobular carcinoma of the breast shows infiltrating smallmonomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern is shownbelow.Lobular carcinoma of breastIndian file pattern1212
